entries: Kiedy stwór wytoczy przeciwko tobie trafienie krytyczne, rzuć d20. Na 11 lub wyżej, atak nadal trafia, ale nie zadaje obrażeń krytycznych.

entries.name: Fluent Liar
entries: Kiedy wykonujesz test Charisma (Deception) i wynik jest mniejszy niż 10, możesz potraktować go jako 10.

entries.name: Blinding Strike
entries: Kiedy trafisz stworzenie atakiem bronią, możesz zmusić cel do wykonania rzutu ratującego Konstytucję. W przypadku nieudanego testu, cel jest {@condition blinded} do końca twojej następnej tury. Po użyciu tej umiejętności nie możesz tego zrobić ponownie, dopóki nie weźmiesz krótkiego długiego odpoczynku.
Wampir w zbroi kłębiącej się z cieniami wychodzi z dymu nad znakiem. Kiwa głową i rzuca swój czarny miecz długi do Twoich stóp.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: W każdej z twoich dłoni otwiera się wściekłe, kocie oko. Te oczy nie zapewniają żadnych dodatkowych zmysłów.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Nie jest tajemnicą, że Vecna, Mistrz wszystkiego, co tajne i ukryte, istniał kiedyś jako okrutny lich. Niewielu jednak wie o zdrajcy, który okaleczył okaleczonego Pana.

Gdy Vecna doszedł do władzy, pod jego czarnym sztandarem wyrosły armie umarłych. Wśród tych nieumarłych legionów pojawił się wampir Kas, cień śmierci odziany w żelazo. Vecna uczynił Kas'a swoim drugim dowódcą, obdarowując go mieczem, który osobiście wykuł z czarnego metalu spadającego z gwiazd. Kas i jego niesławne ostrze przez lata nękały armie Vecny, pochłaniając niezliczone dusze w imieniu licha, tworząc legendę tak krwawą, jak okrutny był jego pan.

Po znacznych stratach na polu walki, osłabiony Vecna wrócił na swój tron, gdzie zastał czekającego Kas. Uzbrojony w swoje czarne ostrze zdrajca Kas uderzył i doszło do tytanicznej bitwy. Podczas walki, pomimo ciemnych mocy Vecny, Kas odciął lewą rękę licha od jego ciała i wyciął oko z jego twarzy. Obawiając się swojej zagłady, Vecna użył szaleńczo niebezpiecznej magii, która unicestwiła zarówno jego, jak i Kas - tak się wydawało.

Jednak w jakimś mglistym królestwie, którego bogowie unikają, Vecna i Kas jakoś kontynuowali istnienie i walkę przez wieki. W końcu, dzięki mrocznej, pierwotnej magii, Vecna uciekła, wznosząc się na wyżyny boskości. Kas tymczasem zaginął w eterze, stając się śladowym elementem.

entries.name: Influence
entries: Jeśli zawrzesz słaby pakt z Kasem, wpływa on na Twoją osobowość w jeden lub oba z poniższych sposobów.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: Gardzę nieumarłymi i zabijam każdego, kogo spotkam.

items.name: Bond
entries: Powinieneś zniszczyć swoich wrogów używając podstępu, zdrady i złośliwości.

optionalfeature.name: Otiax
entries: Klucz do bramy {@i Vestige Level 5, Pact DC 16}

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: Podczas więzi z Otiax, zyskujesz biegłość w {@item thieves' tools|phb}.

entries.name: Fog Sight
entries: Możesz widzieć normalnie przez zaciemnienie spowodowane mgłą, chmurami, dymem lub innym podobnym efektem.

entries.name: Obscuring Mist
entries: Przywołujesz kłębiącą się chmurę niebieskiej mgły, przesłaniającą okolicę. Możesz rzucić zaklęcie {@spell fog cloud} bez użycia slotu na zaklęcie.

entries.name: Fog Hammer
entries: Potrafisz zamienić mgłę wokół siebie w kłębiące się kosmyki mgły, które uderzają w twoich wrogów z brutalną siłą. Jako akcję możesz wykonać atak zaklęciem w walce wręcz przeciwko stworzeniu w promieniu 10 stóp, zadając 2d6 + twój modyfikator Charyzmy przy trafieniu. Możesz użyć Mglistego Młota do wykonania ataku okazjonalnego przeciwko stworzeniom w promieniu 5 stóp.
Na 15 poziomie możesz wykonać dwa ataki Mgłowym Młotem jako akcję; na 19 poziomie możesz wykonać trzy ataki Mgłowym Młotem jako akcję.

entries.name: Unlock
entries: Skupiasz swoją mgłę na zamku, który widzisz, otwierając go myślą. Możesz rzucić to zaklęcie {@spell knock} bez użycia slotu na zaklęcie. Po rzuceniu tego zaklęcia musisz odpocząć krótko lub długo, zanim rzucisz je ponownie.

entries.name: Death Fog
entries: Na 15 poziomie możesz stworzyć wybuch błękitnej mgły, która wysysa życie z istot, które mają pecha znaleźć się w jej zasięgu. Możesz rzucić to zaklęcie {@spell cloudkill} bez użycia slotu na zaklęcie. Po rzuceniu tego zaklęcia musisz długo odpoczywać, zanim rzucisz je ponownie.

Wewnątrz pieczęci pojawia się zamknięta brama, z której wyłaniają się kosmyki niebieskiej mgły, przesłaniające to, co znajduje się za nią. Brama głośno się trzęsie i grzechocze, a za nią słychać poszarpany oddech, gdyż mgła skrywa jakąś niewyraźną, ale straszną postać.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Otaczają Cię cienkie wisiorki niebieskiej mgły, nawet przy najsilniejszym wietrze.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Otiax jest nieco skomplikowany, ponieważ wydaje się, że powstał poza znaną kosmologią płaszczyzn. Kilka źródeł magii paktu wspomina o jakiejś płaszczyźnie lub miejscu zwanym Dalekim Królestwem, ale większość nie oferuje żadnego wyjaśnienia przeszłości Otiaxa. Niektóre z nich twierdzą nawet, że Otiax jest w jakiś sposób kluczem do dotarcia do Dalekiego Królestwa, ale to przypuszczenie ma więcej wspólnego z wyglądem Otiaxa niż z jakimikolwiek prawdziwymi dowodami na jego naturę. Ponieważ Otiax nigdy nie mówi, nie może rzucić światła na tę kwestię. Wiązanie się z nim jest bardziej kwestią instynktu i woli niż rozważań.

entries.name: Influence
entries: Jeśli zawrzesz słaby pakt z Otiaxem, wpływa on na Twoją osobowość w jeden lub oba z poniższych sposobów.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: W konfrontacji z nieotwartymi drzwiami lub bramami staję się niespokojny i nerwowy.

items.name: Bond
entries: Nie mogę pozwolić, by zamek pozostał zabezpieczony. Kiedykolwiek widzę klucz, muszę spróbować użyć go do otwarcia odpowiedniego zamka.

optionalfeature.name: Tenebrous
entries: Cień, który był {@i Vestige Level 5, Pact DC 16}

entries.name: Slay Light
entries: Podczas gdy jesteś związany z Tenebrous, twoje nowo odkryte zamiłowanie do ciemności może odstraszyć zapalone płomienie i ogniki. W swojej turze możesz zgasić wszelkie niemagiczne płomienie, które widzisz w promieniu 100 stóp i które mieszczą się w sześcianie o boku 10 stóp (nie wymaga to żadnej akcji).

Dodatkowo możesz zakończyć pojedynczy czar 3 poziomu niższego, który emituje obszar światła jako akcję. Gdy raz zgasisz magiczne światło, nie możesz tego zrobić ponownie, dopóki nie zakończysz krótkiego lub długiego odpoczynku.

entries.name: Grave Darkness
entries: Możesz rzucić zaklęcie {@spell darkness} jako akcję bonusową, nie wydając strzały zaklęcia ani składników zaklęcia. Dodatkowo, gdy rzucasz zaklęcie, aktywujesz jeden z poniższych efektów w obrębie ciemności, który wpływa na wybrane przez ciebie istoty. Efekty te trwają przez 1 minutę lub do momentu, gdy ciemność zostanie rozwiana.

items: Cienie potępionych spowijają ciemność i utrudniają poruszanie się, sprawiając, że każda 1 stopa ruchu wewnątrz ciemności kosztuje dodatkowo 1 stopę ruchu. Na 15 poziomie obszar ten staje się nienaturalnie cichy jak na zaklęcie {@spell silence}.

Cienie zaczynają chwytać istoty znajdujące się na tym obszarze i je uwięzić. Każda istota znajdująca się w ciemnościach musi odnieść sukces w rzucie ratunkowym na Wytrzymałość lub zostać skrępowana na czas trwania efektu. Skrępowana istota może powtórzyć ten rzut na początku każdej swojej tury, aby zakończyć efekt na sobie wcześniej lub zostać uwolniona przez inną istotę używającą swojej akcji do wykonania testu Wytrzymałości DC 15.

Nieumarły manifestuje się w ciemności i patroluje ją. Stworzenie to znajduje się pod twoją kontrolą, zgodnie z zaklęciem {@spell animate dead}, musi być nieumarłym o Wyzwaniu 3 lub niższym i może widzieć w tej ciemności. Nieumarła istota znika na koniec czasu trwania, jeśli spadnie do 0 HP lub jeśli kiedykolwiek zakończy swoją turę w jasnym świetle. Na 17. poziomie, za jednym użyciem tej umiejętności przywołujesz drugiego nieumarłego tego samego rodzaju.

entries.name: Sense the Shadows
entries: Możesz normalnie widzieć w magicznych i niemagicznych ciemnościach, na odległość 120 stóp. Dodatkowo, poprzez koncentrację jako akcję, możesz wyczuć obecność i liczbę wszystkich żywych istot w promieniu 30 stóp od ciebie, ale nie ich dokładne położenie.

entries.name: Rime of Emptiness
entries: Tenebrous daje ci zimny smutek otchłani, który możesz uwolnić, zadając ból swoim przeciwnikom. Wszystkie twoje ataki bronią do walki wręcz zadają dodatkowo 1d4 obrażeń zimnych i 1d4 obrażeń nekrotycznych.

entries.name: Flicker
entries: Tenebrous przyznaje ci zdolność do znikania w cieniu w najbardziej odpowiednich momentach. Jako reakcja, gdy stworzenie wykonuje przeciwko tobie roll ataku, możesz rzucić czar {@spell blink} bez wydawania slotu na zaklęcie lub składników zaklęcia i natychmiast rzucić pierwsze d20, zgodnie z efektem zaklęcia. Po rzuceniu tego zaklęcia musisz zakończyć krótki lub długi odpoczynek, zanim rzucisz je ponownie.

Cień, wyraźnie ciemniejszy niż jakakolwiek ciemność, skupia się na znaku. Rozciąga się i wznosi do postaci mężczyzny, niemożliwie wychudzonego, jakby ktoś wycisnął z niego całą esencję, pozostawiając jedynie cień.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Wydaje się, że masz drugi cień rzucany za sobą, nawet gdy nie ma światła, które by go tworzyło.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Kilka wieków temu, wielki władca demonów Orcus szukał boskości i osiągnął ją. Zabity i wskrzeszony przez przypływ negatywnej energii, korpulentny demon powstał jako Tenebrous, bóg ciemności i nieśmiertelności. Przez pewien czas podróżował po planach w tej postaci, zabijając innych bogów w dążeniu do zdobycia większej mocy. Dopiero gdy zabił Primusa i rozpoczął Wielki Marsz Modronów, odzyskał Różdżkę Orcusa i swoją prawdziwą, śmiertelną postać.

Prawdziwa boskość nigdy nie może całkowicie zaniknąć. Strzępy boskiej mocy, które Orcus zrzucił, pozostały nietknięte, stając się śladem. Tak więc Tenebrous wciąż istnieje jako blade odbicie tego, czym kiedyś był, cień cienia.

entries.name: Influence
entries: Jeśli zawrzesz słaby pakt z Tenebrousem, wpływa on na twoją osobowość w jeden lub oba z poniższych sposobów.

items.name: Bond
entries: Strata czegoś lub kogoś drogiego dla mnie, albo strach we mnie, że stracę coś lub kogoś na zawsze, głęboko boli w moim sercu.

items.name: Flaw
entries: Moje sprawy i samopoczucie nie są przedmiotem zainteresowania moich sojuszników. Sam sobie z tym poradzę.

optionalfeature.name: Andromalius
entries: The Woeful Błazen {@i Vestige Level 6, Pact DC 18}

entries.name: Catch in the Act
entries: Gdy jesteś związany z Andromaliusem i przytomny, nie możesz zostać zaskoczony. Również kontrole Charyzmy (Deception) i Zręczności (Sleight of Hand) wykonywane przeciwko tobie mają minus.

entries.name: Blindsense
entries: Jeśli jesteś w stanie słyszeć, jesteś świadomy położenia każdej ukrytej lub niewidzialnej istoty w odległości 10 stóp od ciebie.

entries.name: Interception
entries: Jako reakcję, gdy istota, którą widzisz w promieniu 60 stóp, wykonuje test umiejętności, atak lub rzut ratunkowy, możesz w nadprzyrodzony sposób zawalić jego próbę, a rzut jest wykonywany z minusem. Po wykonaniu tej czynności nie możesz użyć tej cechy ponownie, aż do zakończenia krótkiego lub długiego odpoczynku.

entries.name: Laugh to Tears
entries: Możesz rzucić zaklęcie {@spell Tasha's hideous laughter} bez wydawania slotu na zaklęcie lub składników zaklęcia.

entries.name: Ancient's Jig
entries: Możesz rzucić {@spell Otto's irresistible dance} bez wydawania slotu na zaklęcie. Po rzuceniu tego zaklęcia musisz zrobić długi odpoczynek, zanim rzucisz je ponownie.
Stoi przed Tobą mężczyzna w średnim wieku, szczupły, w stroju błazna. Każde z jego ramion rozdziela się w łokciu na tuzin przedramion i tuzin dłoni, które razem żonglują 24 oddzielnymi przedmiotami.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Zyskujesz dodatkową cyfrę na każdej kończynie. Ten dodatek uniemożliwia noszenie normalnych rękawic lub rękawic, ale magiczne rękawice i rękawice zmieniają kształt, by pasować do ciebie.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Niegdyś zwiastun Olidammara, boga sztuczek i kradzieży, Andromalius na łożu śmierci wyrzekł się kradzieży i psot, żałując wszystkich działań, jakie podjął w imieniu swego boga za życia. W ten sposób miał nadzieję wykraść duszę swemu bóstwu, dokonując w ten sposób największej kradzieży i psikusa w historii i udowadniając, że jest najbardziej godny łaski swego boga.

Na początku rozgniewany zdradą Andromaliusa, Olidammara szybko zrozumiał ironię chwili i wybuchnął śmiechem. Jednak dobry humor boga trwał krótko, ponieważ zdał sobie sprawę, że przyjęcie duszy Andromaliusa byłoby równoznaczne z uniemożliwieniem kradzieży i zepsuciem żartu. Ponieważ Olidammara nie chciała pozwolić, by tak sprytny sługa trafił do królestwa innego boga, odpłaciła swemu słudze po stokroć - wykradła duszę Andromaliusza z kosmosu, czyniąc z niej ślad. Nie wiadomo, czy Andromalius uznał ten wynik za zaszczyt, czy nie.

entries.name: Influence
entries: Jeśli zawrzesz słaby pakt z Andromaliusem, wpływa on na twoją osobowość w jeden lub oba z poniższych sposobów.

items.name: Ideal
entries: {@i Property}. Jestem przeciwny kradzieży w każdej postaci i będę wychodził z siebie, aby karać złodziei.

items.name: Flaw
entries: Uwielbiam powodować małe nieszczęścia - zwłaszcza nieporozumienia między przyjaciółmi i przypadki pomylenia tożsamości.

optionalfeature.name: Chupoclops
entries: Harbinger of Forever {@i Vestige Level 6, Pact DC 18}

entries.name: Monstrous Bite
entries: Gdy jesteś związany z Chupoclopsem, twoja dolna szczęka powiększa się i wyrastają z niej ostre jak brzytwa kły. Możesz użyć ataku bez broni, aby ugryźć istotę, zadając 1d8 obrażeń przy trafieniu.

entries.name: Monstrous Reach
entries: You can suddenly stretch and extend your appendages outward. The range of your unarmed strikes increases by 5 feet.

entries.name: Ghost Touch
entries: Your melee attacks overcome damage reduction against incorporeal undead, such as spectres and wraiths. Additionally, your attacks and spells affect creatures on the Ethereal Plane normally as if they were on the Material Plane. After striking an incorporeal enemy with an attack, spells and attacks effect it as if it were of the material plane until the beginning of your next turn

entries.name: Soulsense
entries: You possess a special blindsense with a range of 10 feet which can detect the exact location of living creatures which aren't constructs or elementals.

entries.name: Ethereal Jaunt
entries: You can magically shift from the plane you currently occupy to the Ethereal Plane or return to your plane as a bonus action. You may move no further than 15 feet from where you originated on the Ethereal Plane.

A massive spider leg appears out of nowhere and strikes the center of the seal. Only of the potion of the massive body is visible above the seal, as it shifts and moves until an oddly tusked arachnoid face.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Your lower jaw increases in size and razor sharp fangs sprout from it.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Chupoclops, once a supposed harbinger of the end of existence, was a titanic, spiderlike creature that stalked the Ethereal Plane. Legend has it that the gods trapped the monstrous Chupoclops in the realm of ghosts to prevent it from devouring hope, but it was destined to escape and sate its hunger during the end times.

Because Chupoclops was a terror to both the living and the undead, a group composed of legendary heroes and infamous villains, some alive and some ghosts, set out to murder Chupoclops and thus accomplish what deities could not. The furious battle lasted for seven days, and each day ended with the death of one member of the group that had come to kill the great monster. On the last day, the last hero struck down Chupoclops with her dying blow.

Chupoclops, never a creature defined by the normal rules of the universe, became a vestige after its death. Binder scholars claim that adventurers still encounter its enormous corpse in the misty Ethereal Plane. Now that the monster can no longer destroy hope, some say it will exist forever, and thus, so will the world.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Chupoclops, it influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I can't help but be pessimistic. At best, I'm quietly resigned to my own failure, and at worst, I go out of my way to convince others of their hopelessness.

items.name: Bond
entries: When I have idle time, I spend it lingering on the border Ethereal Plane, gazing longingly into the abyss, searching for something. I know not what.

optionalfeature.name: Geryon
entries: The Deposed Lord {@i Vestige Level 6, Pact DC 18}

entries.name: Devil's Sight
entries: You can see normally in magical and nonmagical darkness, to a range of 120 feet.

entries.name: Acidic Gaze
entries: As an action, select 1 creature you can see that can also see you within 30 feet to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 3d6 acid damage and takes an additional 3d4 damage at the beginning of its turn.
This ability's damage increases when you reach 17th level (4d8 / 4d4).

entries.name: Swift Flight
entries: You gain a flight speed equal to your base walking speed. However, you must begin and end your movement on solid ground, otherwise you fall. Beginning at 18th level, as a bonus action, you can cast the spell fly. After casting this spell, you must take a short or long rest before casting it again.

entries.name: Terrifying Glare
entries: As an action, each creature you choose that you can see which can also see you within 30 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is magically frightened for 1 minute. After using this ability, you must complete a short or long rest before using it again.

entries.name: Eyebite
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell eyebite}. After casting this spell, you must take a long rest before casting it again.

A pit fiend with 6 green eyes rises from the sign. It's skin is cracked like broken pottery and is missing pieces in places, revealing that the body is hollow, illuminated internally with a sickly green light.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Two extra pairs of devilish eyes with green lids and yellow, catlike irises open on your head.

entries.name: Legend
entries: As one of the legendary Lords of the Nine, Geryon ruled Stygia, the frozen fifth layer of Hell. During a great upheaval known as the Reckoning, Geryon secretly supported the greatest of the arch devils, Asmodeus, against his rivals. When the armies of the opposing lords met to decide who would take Asmodeus's power, Geryon blew his horn. At his signal, the armies turned against their leaders, the usurpers were thrown down, and Asmodeus reestablished his right to rule all Baator. Asmodeus returned them to power, but rather than reward Geryon, he gave his lone supporter's power and position to another.

Geryon's fate after losing his position is unclear, but some binder scholars maintain that Asmodeus held one more betrayal in store for him. The ruler of the Nine Hells had always hungered for the souls of those who had lost their faith, and Geryon's powerful soul made a fine meal.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Geryon, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I conspire in secret among my friends to accomplish my goals.

items.name: Ideal
entries: {@i Loyalty.} If I see someone as my ally, I trust them completely.

optionalfeature.name: Zagan
entries: Duke of Disappointment {@i Vestige Level 6, Pact DC 18}

entries.name: Durable Form
entries: While bound to Zagan, your hit point maximum increases by your binder level.

entries.name: Serpent's Senses
entries: You gain the ability to detect creatures by smell. You have advantage on any skill checks made to track a creature by smell. You also gain a limited form of blindsight: you can detect the presence of any living creature within 30 feet. This ability is disrupted by highly strong smells or any other condition which might block scent.

entries.name: Serpent's Bane
entries: You gain advantage on attacks made against yuan-ti, snakes, or other snake-like creatures. Additionally, you gain resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned.

entries.name: Serpent's Grasp
entries: You gain the ability to grapple foes like a snake. This grants you a number of benefits:

items: Your unarmed strikes deal 1d4 bludgeoning or piercing damage.
When you hit a large or smaller creature with an Unarmed Strike, you may use a bonus action to attempt to grapple it.
You have advantage on attack rolls against a creature you are grappling.
You can use your action to try to pin a creature grappled by you. To do so, make another grapple check. If you succeed, you and the creature are both restrained until the grapple ends.
You can constrict a foe you are grappling as a bonus action, dealing 2d8 + your Strength modifier bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Serpent's Terror
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell fear} without expending a spell slot or spell components. Creatures effected by this spell are also frightened by snakes and snake-like creatures for the duration. After casting this spell, you must take a short or long rest before casting it again
A massive, ogre-like creature rises from the seal. It has a long, serpentine form instead of legs, and each of its arms terminate in a massive, hissing serpent's head.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: You gain a lisp and can't help but speak in a sibilant manner.

entries.name: Legend
entries: In the early days of the world, Zagan was a lord in the yuan-ti empire and ruled over thousands of yuan-ti, and tens of thousands of human slaves which worshipped him. As his power grew, he began to envy godhood, and discovered a ritual to propel him to divinity: a grand ceremony wherein he and his yuan-ti would gather together all his worshipers and slay them.

On the appointed night, in the midst of the slaughter of his slaves, and on the eve of his apotheosis, Zagan was betrayed by one of his own clerics. At a point somewhere between godhood and mortality, Zagan passed on into the void.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Zagan, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Bond
entries: I despise snakes and snake-like creatures. I will attack and attempt to kill any that I see.

items.name: Flaw
entries: I am overly aggressive and domineering towards all I meet.

optionalfeature.name: Acererak
entries: The Devourer {@i Vestige Level 7, Pact DC 20}

entries.name: Vestige of Unlife
entries: Acererak grants you a semblance of lichood while he is bound. You have resistance to cold, lightning, and poison damage.

Additionally, the undead see you as a friend while bound to Acererak. Before making an attack against you, an undead creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature loses the attack. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the creature is immune to this feature for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Undead Healing
entries: Whenever you would take necrotic damage from a source other than a cantrip, you instead regain a number of hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt, up to your hit point maximum.

entries.name: Serpent's Bane
entries: You gain advantage on attacks made against yuan-ti, snakes, or other snake-like creatures. Additionally, you gain resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws made to resist being poisoned.

entries.name: False Life
entries: As a bonus action, you can cast the spell {@spell false life} without a spell slot, as if using a spell slot of 4th level. After casting this spell, you must take a short or long rest before casting it again.

entries.name: Finger of Death
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell finger of death} without expending a spell slot. After casting this spell, you must take a long rest before casting it again.

Dust and smoke form together into a yellowed human skull. One by one, precious gems wink into being, so that each eye socket and the space of every tooth becomes occupied by a shining diamond, ruby, emerald, or sapphire.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: A gem replaces one of your teeth. If removed, the gem reverts to a normal tooth.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Acererak was a powerful demi-lich responsible for the infamous Tomb of Horrors. This tomb was his supposed resting place, and was promised to adventures as a dangerous haunt, replete with treasure. And dangerous it was. The Tomb of Horrors slayed more adventurers than almost any other dungeon ever constructed, largely in part to its devious, unforgiving traps. It's notoriety attracted an entire cabal of budding necromancers and cultists to the site, who worshipped the Tomb and Acererak, who they came to call the Devourer.

The most insidious secret of all hidden within the Tomb is that it was not actually Acererak's tomb at all, but a viscous death trap designed to slay adventurers, loot their corpses, and capture their souls; all this in service of Acererak's ultimate goal: merging himself with the Negative Energy Plan, and gaining ultimate control over undeath. In spite of the impossible odds, a group of adventurers ultimately bested the Tomb, discovered the truth of Acererak's plan, and crushed his phylactery, the physical container of his soul.
Normally, such an act would have sent Acererak to the Abyss, but the pull of the Negative Energy Plane proved too strong. Absorbed into the darkness, Acererak persisted on as a vestige.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Acererak, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I obsessively think about death, and how best to cheat it.

items.name: Flaw
entries: I take every opportunity to exercise power over others.

optionalfeature.name: Eurynome
entries: Mother of the Material {@i Vestige Level 7, Pact DC 20}

entries.name: Beastfriend
entries: You can cast the spells {@spell speak with animals}, {@spell locate animals or plants}, and {@spell beast sense} as rituals, and can cast {@spell animal friendship} without expending spell slots or spell components.

entries.name: Answer in the Wind
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell commune with nature} without expending a spell slot. After casting this spell, you must take a short or long rest before casting it again.

entries.name: Eurynome's Wanderlust
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell water walk} without expending a spell slot or spell components. In addition, you can cast the spell {@spell wind walk} once without expending a spell slot. Once you cast {@i wind walk} in this fashion, you cannot cast it again until you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Beastform
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell barkskin} (targeting self only) without expending a spell slot or spell components. In addition, you can cast the spell {@spell polymorph} (targeting self only) once without expending a spell slot. Once you cast {@i polymorph} in this fashion, you cannot cast it again until you complete a short or long rest.

entries.name: Mirage Arcane
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell mirage arcane} without expending a spell slot or spell components. After casting this spell, you must take a long rest before casting it again.
A horrid conglomeration of humanoid, avian, and piscine forms rises from the seal. It's arms are that of an octopus, and legs are that of a hawk.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: You are always perceptively damp.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Eurynome is considered by many to be the first Druid. In life, she was a primordial titan that walked alongside the gods before recorded time. While the Titans battled the essence of chaos of the Outer Planes, Eurynome tired of the endless violence and fled to the unformed Material Plane. Instead she practiced creation, separating the ocean and the sky, filling the ocean with fish and the sky with clouds. Because of her meddling, the gods struck her down and she perished on the Material Plane, her body becoming the first island, and her blood giving birth to the first plants and animals.
Druids of the eldest circles venerate Eurynome for being so in touch with nature that she came to embody it, as they ultimately aspire to.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Eurynome, she influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I am a follower, not a leader. I act in ways my allies did before me.

items.name: Flaw
entries: I see secret motives and possible betrayals behind every action.

optionalfeature.name: Marchosias
entries: King of Killers {@i Vestige Level 7, Pact DC 20}

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain proficiency with hand crossbows, scimitars, shortswords, the disguise kit and the poisoner's kit.

entries.name: Fighting Styles
entries: Przyjmujesz następujący styl walki jako swoją specjalność. Nie możesz wziąć opcji Styl Walki więcej niż raz, nawet jeśli później będziesz mógł wybrać ponownie.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

entries.name: Quick to Act
entries: You have advantage on initiative rolls.

entries.name: Silent and Sure
entries: When you make a Dexterity (Stealth) check and the result is less than 10, you can treat it as a 10.

entries.name: Death Attack
entries: You have advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn in the combat yet. In addition, when you hit a creature that hasn't taken a turn in combat yet, you can deal an additional 8d10 damage. After using this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can use it again.

Body and raiment composed of swirling smoke and cinders, the King of Killers rises from a flame formed above the sign. He wears a crown of fire, beneath which gleam two glowing, hot coals where his eyes should be.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: The pupils of your eyes glow with a red-orange light.

entries.name: Legend
entries: In life, Marchosias was a legendary assassin that refined his slaying skill by targeting other assassins and killers. His choice of target had nothing to do with morals; professional murderers simply provided the greatest challenge.

When he at last met his end, Marchosias's soul was condemned to the Nine Hells, where the spirits of his victims, thugs, slaughterers, executioners, and assassins, waited for him. The condemned souls rose up against their devilish captors, and fell upon Marchosias at once. By the time the devils pulled back the attackers, nothing was left of his soul.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Marchosias, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I am debonair and sly, confident in the knowledge that I have a trick up my sleeve.

items.name: Bond
entries: I will attempt to kill or best any professional assassin or notable killer I encounter.

optionalfeature.name: Balam
entries: The Bitter Angel {@i Vestige Level 8, Pact DC 22}

entries.name: Fighting Styles
entries: Przyjmujesz następujący styl walki jako swoją specjalność. Nie możesz wziąć opcji Styl Walki więcej niż raz, nawet jeśli później będziesz mógł wybrać ponownie.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Angel's Wings
entries: While bound to Balam, you sprout two grotesque, twisted angel's wings, which nonetheless grant you a fly speed equal to your movement speed.

entries.name: Balam's Cunning
entries: You can reroll one ability check, attack roll or saving throw as a reaction, and must use the new result, even if it is worse than the original. You can choose to use this ability, even after the DM says whether the roll succeeds or fails. After using this ability, you must complete a short or long rest before using it again.

entries.name: Prescience
entries: As a bonus action, you can gain a glimpse into the immediate future. Until the end of your next turn, you have advantage on ability checks and attack rolls. Additionally, creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against you during this time. After using this ability, you must complete a long rest before using it again.
Balam is simply a horror. Her body is that of a great purple serpent, and her head consists of the top halves of three horned humanoid heads arranged evenly around a shared gaping maw.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Your voice gains a peculiar quality, becoming both hollow and guttural.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Binders are uncertain of how Balam came to be, but the most prominent understanding is that she was a powerful solar, given an impossible task by her gods. Many binders think she was tasked with eliminating sacrifices to evil gods, which amounted to eliminating the worship of evil gods altogether—a task well beyond what even the good deities could manage. Needless to say, Balam failed in her assignment, and some believe that her foes actually sacrificed her in praise of a dark god.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Balam, she influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Bond
entries: I oppose the forces of evil on principle, but I oppose the forces of good with a personal vengeance in my heart. Only the truly neutral are spared my wrath.

items.name: Ideal
entries: {@i Atheism.} Noone who represents a god can be trusted. I firmly believe that clerics and paladins spread dangerous lies.

optionalfeature.name: Eligor
entries: Dragon's Slayer {@i Vestige Level 8, Pact DC 22}

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, battleaxes, longswords, and warhammers.

entries.name: Eligor's Strength
entries: When you bind Eligor, if your Strength score was lower than 19, it becomes 19.

entries.name: Chromatic Strike
entries: Once per turn, you may choose to deal an additional 2d8 fire, lightning, cold, acid, or poison damage when you hit with a melee attack.

entries.name: Eligor's Skill
entries: You add your proficiency modifier to all Animal Handling checks made when dealing with Eligor's mount, and you gain a number of useful skills in the saddle:

items: You have advantage on melee attack rolls against any unmounted creature that is smaller than your mount.
You can force an attack targeted at your mount to target you instead.

If your mount is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

entries.name: Eligor's Companion
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell find steed} without expending an spell slot. The mount summoned is identical to a Heavy Warhorse, but physically appears to be half dragon. When your pact with Eligor ends, your steed is dismissed.
Fully clad in shining armor, Eligor clatters out of nothingness riding a half-horse-half-dragon abomination.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: One of your hands becomes thickly scaled.

entries.name: Legend
entries: In life, Eligor was a great half-elf dragonslayer. After his death, Tiamat sent her draconic minions to the realms of good deities to claim his soul. Though the gods fought against this, they eventually relented.

One deity, whose name has been lost to history, pursued Tiamat into the underworld, intending to wrest Eligor's soul from his captors. Instead of finding him in bondage, the diety found him in the armor of a draconic champion. Unbeknownst to the other gods, Tiamat had raised him from death to be her champion and enforcer, winning his loyalty through the other gods' abandonment. Eligor and the nameless deity fought, and Eligor lost his life yet again. This time, no deity laid claim to his soul, and Eligor passed on into the void.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Eligor, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Bond
entries: I feel pity for all outcasts, particularly half-elves and half-orcs, and I will make every effort to befriend any such beings I meet.

items.name: Bond
entries: I was deeply wronged by the deities who abandoned me. As such, If able, I will attack humans, elves, or dragons in preference to all others whenever I am in combat.

optionalfeature.name: Halphax
entries: The Angel in the Angle {@i Vestige Level 9, Pact DC 25}

entries.name: Stone Skin
entries: While bound to Halphax you have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons.

entries.name: Halphax's Knowledge
entries: You have advantage on ability checks relating to understanding architecture, buildings, and so on.

entries.name: Secure Shelter
entries: You can cast the spell {@spell Leomund's Tiny Hut} as a ritual.

entries.name: Iron Wall
entries: You can cast {@spell wall of stone} without expending a spell slot or spell components. This wall appears to be made of iron, rather than stone. After casting this spell, you must take a short or long rest before casting it again.

entries.name: Imprison
entries: You can imprison a foe deep underground with but a touch. You can cast the spell {@spell imprisonment} without a spell slot or spell components, and can only choose the burial or hedge prison options. After casting this spell, you must take a long rest before casting it again.
The geometry of the room distorts, one corner stretching into the distance, and snapping back. A gnome holding the implements of an architect now stands in the corner, and approaches the seal.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: Your skin takes on the appearance of cracked stone.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Long ago, the gnomes lived in massive, nigh-impregnable cities that played host to a number of other races. In an event known as the Great Betrayal, the hobgoblin populations of many of these cities banded together and seized the cities for themselves, converting their sturdy walls into prisons for the inhabitants.

The hobgoblins captured gnomish architects and engineers and forced them to fortify the cities. When they kidnapped the wife of the great gnomish architect, Halphax, he crafted the single most impregnable prison in history. When at last the goblinoids were defeated, Halphax's city was the last to fall. The liberating army found Halphax and his wife alone in the prison city: the hobgoblins had killed all but the two of them. Because she could not bear to be the cause of so much tragedy, Halphax's wife took her own life.
The gnomes attempted to apprehend Halphax for his betrayal, but the architect vanished into his city. The armies tore the city down to its foundations as they searched, but he was never seen again.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Halphax, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: My personality is as rigid as my stone skin, and I find it difficult to emote.

items.name: Bond
entries: I never take hostages and always negotiate, rather than fight, if something or someone I care about is held captive.

optionalfeature.name: Orthos
entries: Sovereign of the Howling Dark {@i Vestige Level 9, Pact DC 25}

entries.name: Voidsight
entries: You gain {@sense darkvision} with a range of 60 feet. If you already possess darkvision, its range increases by 60 feet. You can see normally in magical darkness. Additionally, you gain blindsight with a range of 10 feet.

entries.name: Howling Resilience
entries: You gain resistance to cold, fire, lightning, and thunder damage

entries.name: Whispering Wind
entries: As an action, you may send simple messages on the wind to a creature you know. If you are outside, you may send a message of no more than 25 words up to 100 miles from your location.

entries.name: Howling Fury
entries: You are constantly surrounded by a whirling, slashing wind. Any ranged weapon attacks made against you are made at disadvantage.

Additionally, as an action, you can direct the wind to lash out against your foes. As an action, make a ranged spell attack against a foe you can see within 120 feet. On a hit, this creature takes 2d8 slashing + 2d8 thunder + your Charisma modifier force damage and must make a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

entries.name: Whirlwind Breath
entries: As an action, you can exhale a 60 foot cone of blasting, deafening wind. Each creature in the cone must make a Dexterity saving throw; on a failure, a creature takes 7d6 thunder + 7d6 bludgeoning damage, is knocked prone, and is shoved to the nearest edge of the cone. On a successful save, the damage is reduced by half, the creature is not knocked prone, and is only pushed 10 feet away from you. Once you use this ability, you must take a long rest before you can do so again.

A light breeze buffets about the room, then rises into a whistling wind, and finally into a howling gale. Then it stops. A presence not altogether visual, but evident and palpable nonetheless, has arrived on the seal in the midst of the chaos.

entries.name: Physical Sign
entries: You always seem to be buffeted by a breeze that no one else can feel, even when you're indoors.

entries.name: Legend
entries: Orthos might well be the original vestige—the first being to break the boundaries and see past the window of reality to the nothingness beyond. Pact magic texts always mention this entity, and persistent explorers can find its seal represented in art or architecture on most planes, as well as in the ruins of many ancient civilizations. Binder scholars have a thousand theories about Orthos's origins, but none is more than mere supposition. All agree that Orthos is inestimably old, and it has long since shed whatever form and persona it might once have had, becoming an alien and distant being. In deference to its great age and the hallmark of its appearance, binder scholars have dubbed Orthos the Sovereign of the Howling Dark.

entries.name: Influence
entries: If you make a poor pact with Orthos, he influences your personality in one or both of the following ways.

items.name: Personality Trait
entries: I speak only in a whisper.

items.name: Bond
entries: Darkened areas and loud noises make me short of breath and fill me with panic.

optionalfeature.name: Blade Spirit
entries: Commonly found protecting tombs and temples alongside guardian spirits, blade spirits are beings of spite and malice, shaped into the form of a floating, glowing dagger or sword. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: When you use the Attack action to make a melee weapon attack and you hit, you can use a bonus action to deal an additional 1d6 psychic damage to your target.
You can cast the spell {@spell spiritual weapon} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can transform your blade spirit into any type of melee weapon you are proficient with. This weapon is magical and you can use it to make melee weapon attacks.

optionalfeature.name: Cherub
entries: A spirit of grace and divine favor, a cherub manifests as a small, feather-winged humanoid with delicate features. While active, a cherub grants the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell sacred flame} cantrip at will.
You can cast the spell {@spell healing word} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your cherub fire an arrow from its golden bow as a ranged spell attack at a creature you can see within 60 feet. On a hit, this arrow deals 1d8 magical piercing damage.

optionalfeature.name: Frostling
entries: This minor elemental spirit manifests as a mass of spinning, fractal ice shards. While it is active, you gain access to the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell ray of frost} cantrip at will.
You gain resistance to cold damage.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your frostling fling a shard of ice at a creature you can see within 60 feet as a ranged spell attack. If the shard hits, it deals the target 1d6 cold damage, and it explodes, dealing 1d4 cold damage to all creatures within 5 feet of the target.

optionalfeature.name: Ghost
entries: A ghost is a spirit of regret or woe which haunts a place following its death; the binder gives it a way to escape the confines of its place of death. A ghost manifests as a hazy, translucent floating torso of a humanoid of some sort. While active, a ghost grants you the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell chill touch} cantrip at will.
You gain advantage on saving throws against fear effects.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can send your ghost to shock a creature you can see within 30 feet as a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target takes 1d6 necrotic damage and must make a Wisdom saving throw; failure causes the target to be frightened of you until the start of your next turn. Regardless of success or failure, a given creature cannot be affected by this ability more than once every 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Guardian Spirit
entries: A guardian spirit is a commonly found minor spirit, usually charged with protecting a tomb or temple from intruders; it manifests as a floating, plate-sized glowing ring surrounding a protective sigil. Once bound to a binder and active, it grants the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell blade ward} cantrip at will.
Your AC increases by 1.
You can cast the spell {@spell shield} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.

optionalfeature.name: Gustling
entries: This minor elemental spirit manifests as a ball of swirling, opaque air. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can use your reaction to cause a ranged spell attack made against you to be made with disadvantage.
You can cast the spell {@spell fog cloud} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can fling a ball of swirling air at a creature you can see within 60 feet as a ranged spell attack. On a hit, that creature takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage, and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be shoved 10 feet away or knocked prone, your choice.

optionalfeature.name: Hell Hound
entries: Hell hounds are minor hunting spirits, used by devils and demons to track down those who attempt to escape from a deal with such beings. They manifest as 4 legged, dog-like creatures that seem to breathe flames. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell guidance} cantrip at will.
You can cast the spell {@spell burning hands} with your hell hound as the point of origin. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can move your hound up to 30 feet and have it attempt to bite a creature within 5 feet of it. The bite is a melee spell attack, and deals 1d4 piercing damage and 1d4 fire damage. Your hell hound cannot move further than 60 feet from you at any time.

optionalfeature.name: Imp
entries: This minor demonic spirit is a manifestation of evil thought and malevolence. It manifests as a small, winged, horned humanoid, hence its name. While your imp is active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You gain {@sense darkvision} with a range of 60 feet.
You can cast the spell {@spell hex} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must complete a short or long rest before doing so again.

On your turn, as a bonus action, you can move your imp up to 30 feet away from you towards a creature you can see and have it make a melee spell attack, dealing 1d8 magical slashing damage. The imp immediately returns to your side afterwards.

optionalfeature.name: Lantern
entries: This minor divine spirit is a being of pure goodness and divine judgement. It manifests as a fist-sized ball of light, which sheds light as a torch. While your lantern is active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You have resistance to radiant damage.
You can cast the spell {@spell bless} without a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you must take a short or long rest before you can do so again.

On your turn, you can use your bonus action to have your lantern fire a beam of light as a ranged spell attack at a creature you can see within 60 feet. This beam deals 1d8 radiant damage, or 2d8 radiant damage if the target is a demon, devil, or undead.

optionalfeature.name: Pixie
entries: This tiny, capricious spirit is just as flighty as its namesake. Born from the magic of nature and the woods, a pixie manifests as a tiny, butterfly-winged humanoid. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell minor illusion} cantrip at will.
You can cast {@spell disguise self} without using a spell slot.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your pixie fire a poisonous dart as a ranged spell attack at a creature you can see within 60 feet. A creature hit by this dart take 1d10 poison damage.

optionalfeature.name: Poltergeist
entries: A spirit of warning and mischief, a poltergeist is different from other minor spirits in that it does not manifest in a visible form. Instead, it manifests as constant phenomenon around you: flickering candles, frigid temperature drops, object mysteriously floating, etc. While active, a poltergeist grants the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell mage hand} cantrip at will.
You can cast the spell {@spell unseen servant} without using a spell slot.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your poltergeist fling a small object as a ranged spell attack against a creature you can see within 60 feet. This attack deals 1d10 piercing, bludgeoning, or slashing damage, as appropriate to the object.

optionalfeature.name: Stormling
entries: This minor elemental spirit manifests as a small, crackling ball of electricity, which sheds light as a torch. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell shocking grasp} cantrip at will.
You gain resistance to lightning damage.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your stormling launch a bolt of electricity as a ranged spell attack at a creature you can see within 60 feet. This attack deals 1d6 lightning damage, and you gain advantage on the attack roll if the target is wearing metal armor.

optionalfeature.name: Torchling
entries: This minor elemental spirit manifests as a small, burning ball of fire or magma, which sheds light as a torch. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell fire bolt} cantrip at will.
You gain resistance to fire damage.
As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your torchling fire a bolt of flame as a ranged spell attack at a creature you can see within 60 feet. This attack deals 1d8 fire damage.

optionalfeature.name: Will-o'-the-Wisp
entries: A spirit composed of fearful and spiteful energy, the will-o'-the-Wisp manifests as a hazy ball of blue flame, which sheds light as a torch. While active, you gain the following abilities:

items: You can cast the {@spell dancing lights} cantrip at will.
You can cast the spell {@spell faerie fire} without using a spell slot. Once you use this ability, you cannot do so again until you take a short or long rest.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can have your wisp fling a bolt of ghostly flame at a creature you can see within 60 feet as a ranged spell attack. This bolt deals 1d6 psychic damage on a hit, and the creature is outlined in blue light. The next attack made against this creature adds 1d4 to the attack roll.

feat.name: Exorcist
entries: You have been taught secret techniques for the removal of possessing spirits.

items: When you make a melee attack against a fey, fiend, or undead, you ignore that creature's damage resistances.

You can use your action to touch a creature within your reach and determine if the creature is possessed or under the effects of an enchantment spell. If so, you learn the type of spirit possessing the creature or the spell enchanting it.

entries: By presenting a holy symbol to a creature within 10 feet as an action, you can attempt an exorcism ritual. If the creature is possessed by a spirit, the possessing spirit must make a Wisdom saving throw, with a DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier. On a failure, the spirit is expelled, and it cannot enter that creature again for 24 hours. On a success, the creature is immune to exorcism attempts for 24 hours.

If the target of your exorcism is a creature with the Soul Binding feature, it becomes unable to use any power or ability provided by its vestiges, except for Bonus Proficiencies, and the vestige's Physical Sign and Influence, for 1 minute.

feat.name: Novice Occultist
entries: You have learned the hidden ways of pactmaking, and can summon a few minor spirits to your aid.

items: You gain the {@class binder|mfovbinder|Soul Binding|binder|null|soul binding 1} feature.

You bind one {@filter Minor Spirit|optionalfeatures|source=null|feature type=ms} to your service, and can use its abilities. No matter how many minor spirits you have bound to you, you can only have one active at a time.

entries: You learn to summon a {@filter first level vestige|optionalfeatures|source=null|feature type=vs1}, with difficulty. As an action, you can bind this vestige and use its powers and abilities, while you maintain concentration on the binding as you would a spell. If you lose concentration, or after 1 minute, the vestige is expelled. You always make a poor pact with this vestige, unless you have levels in a class that grants you vestige binding.
After summoning this vestige, you must take a long rest before you can summon it again.

feat.name: Witch Hunter
entries: You have experience in the detection and elimination of warlocks, occultists, and creatures possessed by foul spirits.

items: You gain resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage (your choice when you gain this feat.)
You can instantly identify a creature that has cast a spell within the last 24 hours.

When you hit a creature with a melee attack, you can use a bonus action to disrupt its magic. This creature must make a Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on spell attack rolls it makes until the beginning of your next turn. The DC equals 10 or half the damage dealt, whichever is higher.

item.name: Ritual Implements
entries: This pouch contains the tools necessary to summon forth a vestige from the Void, including candles, incense, multi-colored sands, powdered metals, vials of ritual components, a vial of ink and quill, a ritual knife, several pieces of chalk, and an incomplete codex of vestiges and seals. Proficiency with these implements allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the Charisma check made when binding a vestige.

item.name: Chime of Suppression
item.reqAttune: by a creature with the soul binding feature
entries: You can ring this bell as a bonus action to disrupt one vestige bound to yourself. For 1 minute, that vestige is suppressed: you do not gain any of the vestige's features, not do you show the vestige's Physical Sign or Influence.

item.name: Sould Lens, +1
entries: This deceptively simple looking sapphire and gold monocle is an invaluable asset to any pact-maker, augmenting and enhancing a bound vestige's abilities. While worn, you gain a +1 bonus to all attack rolls and saving throw DCs for your vestige powers and abilities.

item.name: Sould Lens, +2
entries: This deceptively simple looking sapphire and gold monocle is an invaluable asset to any pact-maker, augmenting and enhancing a bound vestige's abilities. While worn, you gain a +2 bonus to all attack rolls and saving throw DCs for your vestige powers and abilities.

item.name: Sould Lens, +3
entries: This deceptively simple looking sapphire and gold monocle is an invaluable asset to any pact-maker, augmenting and enhancing a bound vestige's abilities. While worn, you gain a +3 bonus to all attack rolls and saving throw DCs for your vestige powers and abilities.

item.name: Spirit Stone
item.reqAttune: by a creature with the soul binding feature
entries: This ornately carved, fist-sized tetrahedron seems to be made of a precious stone, but it is impossible to tell of which variety. By performing a ritual during a short rest, you can bind one of your Minor Spirits into the Spirit Stone; once done, the stone floats nearby, and the spirit manifests itself around it. While bound to the stone, that spirit does not count against your number of active spirits. You can expel and bind a new spirit into the stone by performing the ritual again.

item.name: Teeth of Dahlver-Nar
entries: These teeth are mysterious in origin, and are inextricably linked to the vestige Dahlver-Nar. To attune to one, you must remove your own tooth, and put a tooth of Dahlver-Nar in its place, which deals you 1 point of damage. You can then cast the spell associated with that tooth at will. You can choose your spellcasting ability for these spells, but once made, you cannot change this selection.
There are a number of known teeth, each associated with a particular vestige:

item.name: Universal Seal
item.reqAttune: by a creature with the soul binding feature
entries: This seal is sewn into silks and painted with magical paints. Functionally, it is an amalgamation of many seals, reusing the most common geometries to all vestige seals. When you negotiate your pacts following a long rest, you can use the universal seal to summon all your vestiges at once (requiring only 1 minute, no matter how many vestiges you intend to bind,) and make a single Charisma check against the highest Pact DC. On a success, you make a good pact with all of your vestiges. On a failure, you make a poor pact with all your vestiges.

item.name: Vestige Phylactery
item.reqAttune: by a creature with the soul binding feature
entries: This ornately carved cube houses a vestige. When you negotiate your pacts following a long rest, you can bind a single vestige to this phylactery. In a ritual requiring 1 round of concentration, you can expel one vestige you are bound to and exchange it with the vestige held in the phylactery. After binding this vestige, you cannot use any of its powers or abilities for 1d4 rounds. A vestige bound in this way always forms a poor pact.

This wicked-looking blade is cut from black, volcanic glass, and is covered in small, precisely-carved vestige seals. A creature bound to a vestige gains a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Additionally, the athame can be used to augment a vestige binding ritual, and you have advantage on the Charisma check made to bind a vestige while you hold it.

classFeature.name: Soul Binding
entries: In your studies, you have uncovered the means to pierce the very fabric of the planes and call to what lives beyond. You learn how to contact a vestige and bind it to a magical agreement. By doing so, you allow a vestige to reside in your soul, and adopt its physical sign on your body. For a list of vestiges and their abilities, see the {@book Vestige Codex|MFoV-B|0}.

entries.name: Pact Negotiation
entries: Following a long rest, you can perform a binding ritual. This process, which takes 1 minute for each vestige you are attempting to bind, requires calling the vestige by name and title, rendering the intended vestige's seal, and potentially other more esoteric acts. During this ritual, the vestige you contact appears as a hazy phantom, hovering over the seal, and slowly becomes more tangible as the ritual continues.

At the completion of each ritual, you make a Charisma check against the Vestige's Pact DC. On a success, you make a Good Pact and the vestige inhabits your body and soul. It leaves you with a physical Sign of its presence, and grants you its associated powers and abilities. If you fail this check, you forge a Poor Pact. You still gain the powers and abilities granted by the vestige, but it fully imposes its will on your psyche, influencing you to act in a fashion that the vestige finds appropriate.

At 1st level you can bind one vestige, and can bind more vestiges at higher levels, as shown in the Vestiges Bound column of the Binder table. Unless otherwise specified, you can only bind vestiges whose combined level is no greater than your binder level.

entries.name: Renegotiation
entries: Once per day when you finish a short rest, you can choose to perform the ritual of binding again to renegotiate any of the bargains you have made earlier in the day. This allows you to expel a bound vestige early and bind another in its place. When you choose to renegotiate your pacts, you can expel as many vestiges as you wish, and bind a number of vestiges whose combined level is no more than half your binder level (rounded up).

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for all spells and powers granted to you by your vestiges, since you command the power of your vestiges though your force of personality. Use your Charisma score whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a spell or ability granted to you by one of your vestiges.

entries.name: Suppress Sign
entries: When you make a good pact with a vestige, you can use a bonus action to suppress or display the physical sign of that vestige.

classFeature.name: Minor Spirits
entries: Binding a vestige is the culmination of years of study and practice in both summoning magic and possession. As such, a binder can use the runoff magical energy from his Pact Magic to bind weaker spirits and beings into his service with little to no risk. These spirits serve many uses for the binder, acting as familiars, bodyguards, weapons, and armor.

At 2nd level, you perform a ritual which binds a minor spirit to your service, selected from the {@filter Minor Spirits list|optionalfeatures|source=null|feature type=ms}. The spirit manifests itself, hovering around you (though never impeding you). Though it has a visible form, it is not a creature and cannot be targeted or damaged in any way. While that spirit is active, you gain use of any powers or abilities it grants. You can use a bonus action to dismiss or summon your minor spirit, causing its visible from to vanish, but you can only access its powers while it is manifested.

You can bind one additional minor spirit your service at 5th level, 10th level, 14th level, and 18th level. You can have one active spirit at a time, and you can use your bonus action to switch between them. At 10th level, you can have two spirits active at once. When you gain a level in this class, you can choose to replace a minor spirit you can bind with another.

classFeature.name: Trusted Vestige
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you begin to form a stronger relationship with a particular vestige. This vestige will respond more readily to your summons, and is more likely to obey without attempting to subvert the bargain. Choose one vestige that you have previously summoned and remained bound to for a continuous period of no less than 24 hours. You always make a good pact with this vestige.
When you gain a level in this class, you can choose to replace a trusted vestige with another vestige that you can bind at that level.

classFeature.name: Binder's Fate
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your soul begins to show the marks of constant possession by the forces from outside reality. You must choose a destiny to embrace as part of your practice. Select a Binder Fate from the options available.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level, and again at 6th level, 13th level, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Minor Spirits (2)
entries: You may pick a second minor spirit

classFeature.name: Binder's Fate feature
entries: You gain another binder's fate feature

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Adamant Mind
entries: At 9th level, your experience in sharing your mind with otherworldly entities has taught you how to guard your thoughts, and punish those that dare to influence them. You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed or frightened, and on saving throws against any effect that would sense your emotions or read your thoughts.
Additionally, when you succeed on a save against such an effect, the creature that used that ability on you takes psychic damage equal to your binder level + your Charisma modifier.

classFeature.name: Minor Spirits (3)
entries: You can choose another minor spirit to know. Additionally, you can have two minor spirits active at a time

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Binder's Fate feature
entries: You gain another binder's fate feature

classFeature.name: Minor Spirits (4)
entries: You may pick another minor spirit

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Binder's Fate feature
entries: You gain another binder's fate feature

classFeature.name: Minor Spirits (5)
entries: You may pick another minor spirit

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Everlasting Pact
entries: When you reach 20th level, you can form an everlasting pact with a vestige. When you bind a vestige of 2nd level or lower or a trusted vestige, it remains bound to you until you choose to expel it, and it does not count against your total levels of vestiges bound. You can only have 1 vestige bound in this fashion at a time.

subclassFeature.name: Eldritch Fate
entries: Though Binding is not spellcasting in the usual sense, it is not altogether different. Binders who follow the Eldritch Fate learn to take that skill and apply it to magic of the proper sort. As well, they learn to exploit their connection to the vestiges they bind, which they refer to as Anima, taking the power they give and channeling it directly into magical might.

entries.name: Pact Magic
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you have learned to channel the power of your pacts to cast spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the warlock spell list. You learn an additional warlock cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Eldritch Fate Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have. The table also shows what the level those of those spell slots; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your Eldritch Fate spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level warlock spells of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Eldritch Fate Spellcasting table shows when you learn more warlock spells of 1st level or higher.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the warlock spells you know with another spell of your choice from the warlock spell list. A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your Eldritch Fate spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an Eldritch Fate spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Anima Casting
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to exploit your bound vestiges for magical power. As a bonus action, you can convert a vestige you currently have bound into a single spell slot. The spell slot level is equal to the level of the vestige used, but can be no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level. Once you have done so, you lose access to that vestige's powers until you finish a long rest, and you cannot renegotiate your pact with it.

subclassFeature.name: Anima Shield
entries: At 6th level, you force a bound vestige into being your personal watchdog. While you are bound to a vestige, you add your proficiency bonus to your initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Anima Mark
entries: At 13th level, you learn to mix your arcane power with your skills at vestige seal-crafting. During a one minute-long ritual, you inscribe a personal mark on a willing creature you can touch. The mark lasts until dismissed, after which it fades away; it cannot be erased or dispelled by magic short of a wish spell. The mark disappears if you die, or if the creature bearing it dies. Once you mark a creature in this fashion, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest, and you cannot have more than one marked creature at a time.
A marked creature is bonded to you, much the same way you are bonded to your vestiges. This grants a number of benefits to the bonded creature:

items: While you are within 1 mile of your bonded creature, you can communicate telepathically with it, even if you do not share a language.
As long as the creature bearing your mark is on the same plane as you, you know which direction the creature is in. If the creature dies, you are instantly aware of it.

You can choose to cause any spells you cast with a range of Self to affect your bonded creature as well, and you can cast spells with a range of Touch on your bonded creature as long as it is within 60 feet.

As a reaction, you can cause your mark to surge with power. Doing so allows your bonded creature to re-roll a failed attack roll, saving throw, or skill check. You cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Form
entries: At 17th level, you can use your vestige's bonds as a conduit to the Far Realm, gaining powerful insights at a possibly deadly cost. You can expel a vestige you have bound to cast any warlock or sorcerer spell of the same level as the vestige you sacrificed. After expelling a vestige in this way, you cannot renegotiate its pact until you finish a long rest.

You can use this ability to cast spells of a higher level than your pact magic would allow. When using this ability to cast a spell of 5th level or higher, you must make a concentration check with a DC equal to 11 + the spell level: failure causes you to take 1d10 points of unavoidable and irreducible psychic damage for each level of the spell.
Once you use this ability, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Occult Fate
entries: Vestiges are deeply enigmatic things, and binding them is a volatile practice. Binders that are ordained in the Occult Fate seek to unravel the deepest mysteries of Pact Magic through ritual and study, focusing their skill on the art and skill of binding above all else.

entries.name: Trusted Vestiges
entries: When you select this fate at 3rd level, you can select 2 additional trusted vestiges, which must be of a level less than your highest vestige level.
You can select two additional trusted vestiges at 7th, 13th, and 17th level.

entries.name: Extra Vestige
entries: At 3rd level, as an action, you can bind one of your trusted vestiges with a poor pact without it counting against your daily limit of vestige levels, or number of vestiges bound. You can expel this vestige normally, but you cannot renegotiate a new vestige in its place. At 13th level, you always bind this vestige with a good pact.

This vestige is expelled after 1 minute. At 7th level, this duration increases: the vestige is expelled after 10 minutes. At 13th level the vestige is expelled when you take a short or long rest, and at 17th level only when you take a long rest. Once you use this ability, you must finish a long rest to do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Share Vestige
entries: Starting at 6th level, as an action, you can expend the use of your Extra Vestige feature and bind it to another willing host (that is not a binder) which you can see within 30 feet. This host uses your binder level, spell attack bonus, and vestige save DC for any abilities granted by this vestige. A host that is not a binder always forges a poor pact with a vestige. If you are already bound to your Extra Vestige, you can transfer the vestige to a willing host or back to yourself as an action.

subclassFeature.name: Empty Vessel
entries: Starting at 13th level,you can expend the use of your Extra Vestige feature by binding it to a corpse or skeleton as a 10 minute ritual, animating the body as per the spell animate dead, but with the following differences:

items: The undead gains all the features as it would being bound to the chosen vestige.
The undead can ignore your mental commands if doing so would prevent it from acting in accordance with both influences of its bound vestige.

subclassFeature.name: Medium
entries: At 13th level, you learn to channel vestiges with much greater efficiency and fluidity. When renegotiating your pacts during a short rest, you can expel any or all of your current vestiges, and make new pacts as if it was following a long rest. You still cannot exceed your maximum number of vestiges bound at one time.

subclassFeature.name: Master Summoner
entries: By 17th level, you learn to expedite the binding process to the point that you can swap vestiges in the blink of an eye. As an action, you can expel a bound vestige and bind a new vestige, following the standard rules for renegotiation. You cannot use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Sealed Fate
entries: A binder of the Sealed Fate forms a true partnership with a specific vestige. You become that vestige's champion, taking its seal as your symbol and actively advancing your patron's desires and goals. In return, your patron grants her powers beyond that of other binders, enhancing your ability to fight on its behalf.

entries.name: Patron Vestige
entries: Starting when you choose this fate at 3rd level, you venerate your trusted vestige as your patron, your bulwark against those that might harm you. While bound to your trusted vestige, you gain a fighting style from among: {@optfeature Dueling}, {@optfeature Great Weapon Fighting}, {@optfeature Protection}, and {@optfeature Two-Weapon Fighting}, and, while not wearing armor, your AC is equal to 13 + your Dexterity modifier.
When you change your trusted vestige, this new vestige becomes you patron vestige.

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: At 3rd level, you gain proficiency in martial weapons and shields.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: At 6th level, while bound to your trusted vestige, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Patron Strike
entries: At 13th level, your melee and ranged weapon attacks deal additional psychic damage equal to your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Patron's Aegis
entries: At 17th level, your patron shields your form from harm, turning lethal blows and denying your death. When you bind to your trusted vestige, you gain a pool of temporary HP equal to 5 + your binder level. Once per turn, when you strike a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can add a number of temporary HP to this pool equal to half the damage dealt. This pool has a maximum size of twice your Charisma score.
These temporary HP are lost upon breaking your bond with your trusted vestige, and the pool size resets to 5 + your Charisma score when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Twisted Fate
entries: Binders are usually feared and hunted as heretics, or as monsters. As a result of whispered rumors of corruption and heresy, most binders take great pains to keep their craft hidden. Through great practice and great courage do those who take upon themselves the Twisted Fate claim unnatural powers of their own. They embrace the monster that grows in their souls with each pact they form.

entries.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: Starting at 3rd Level, you gain proficiency in your choice of {@skill Intimidation} or {@skill Perception}.

entries.name: Unnatural Weapon
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn to tap into the form-altering abilities of your vestiges and use them to shape your body to your whim. You can grow or shape varying natural weapons from your body, such as horns, fangs, claws, tentacles, etc. Your unarmed strikes deal 1d4 bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage (your choice), which is considered magical for the purposes of bypassing damage resistance and immunity. Also, when you use the Attack action on your turn to make an unarmed strike, you can use a bonus action to make an additional unarmed strike.
At 7th level, your unarmed strike damage increases to 1d6, and at 13th level, it increases to 1d8.

If you are bound to a vestige which augments your unarmed strike in some way, you can use the vestige's unarmed damage (if it is higher than your own) and your unarmed strikes gain a magical +1 bonus to attack and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Alter Skin
entries: At 6th level, you can change the hue and structure of your skin, providing an abnormal benefit. You gain one of the following features of your choice. You can activate and suppress this feature as an action.

entries.name: Adaptive
